quiz.title: Unit 7: Labor Markets (Quiz 9)
quiz.subtitle: 7.9 Monopsony Power: Single Buyer in Labor Markets (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Monopsony, Labor Market Power, Wage Determination, Market Imperfections

questions.question: A monopsony in labor markets occurs when:
options: There is one seller of labor and many buyers
There is one buyer of labor and many sellers
There are many buyers and sellers of labor
questions.explanation: Monopsony is a market structure with a single buyer (employer) facing many sellers (workers), giving the employer significant market power.

questions.question: In a monopsony labor market, the marginal factor cost (MFC) curve lies:
options: On top of the labor supply curve
Unrelated to the labor supply curve
questions.explanation: MFC > wage because to hire additional workers, the monopsonist must raise wages for all workers, not just the marginal ones.

questions.question: A profit-maximizing monopsonist hires workers up to the point where:
questions.explanation: The monopsonist maximizes profit where marginal factor cost equals marginal revenue product (MFC = MRP), then pays the wage indicated by the labor supply curve.

questions.question: Compared to a competitive labor market, a monopsony results in:
questions.explanation: Monopsony leads to both lower wages and lower employment compared to the competitive equilibrium.

questions.question: At the monopsonist's profit-maximizing employment level, the wage paid is:
questions.explanation: Since MFC > wage and the firm hires where MFC = MRP, it follows that wage < MRP at the optimal employment level.

questions.question: The deadweight loss in monopsony represents:
options: The transfer from workers to the employer
The lost gains from trade from reduced employment
The administrative costs of monopsony power
The difference between wage and MRP
questions.explanation: Deadweight loss is the reduction in total economic surplus because employment is restricted below the competitive level.

questions.question: A minimum wage set appropriately in a monopsony market can:
options: Have no effect on the market
questions.explanation: A minimum wage can force the monopsonist to pay a higher wage while also increasing employment by making the MFC constant up to that wage.

questions.question: Oligopsony refers to a labor market with:
questions.explanation: Oligopsony is a market structure where a few large buyers (employers) dominate hiring, giving them collective market power.

questions.question: Real-world examples of monopsony power often occur in:
questions.explanation: Monopsony characteristics appear in company towns, certain professional sports, nursing markets, and specialized occupations with few employers.

questions.question: The elasticity of labor supply facing an employer affects monopsony power because:
options: More elastic supply reduces monopsony power
More elastic supply increases monopsony power
Elasticity has no effect on monopsony power
questions.explanation: When labor supply is more elastic, workers are more responsive to wage differences, making it harder for employers to exercise monopsony power.

questions.question: In a monopsony labor market, the supply curve represents:
options: The relationship between wage and quantity supplied
questions.explanation: The supply curve shows the wage required to attract each additional worker, while the MFC curve accounts for the cost of raising wages for all workers.

questions.question: The Lerner Index for monopsony power measures:
questions.explanation: The monopsony power index = (MRP - Wage) / Wage, indicating the degree to which wages are depressed below workers' marginal revenue product.

questions.question: Factors that can create monopsony power include:
options: Many employers in a local market
questions.explanation: High moving costs, specialized skills, geographic isolation, and search frictions can all reduce worker mobility and create monopsony power.

questions.question: In a monopsony market, if the minimum wage is set at the competitive equilibrium level:
options: Employment will decrease below monopsony level
Employment will increase to competitive level
Wages will fall below competitive level
The employer will gain more power
questions.explanation: Setting the minimum wage at the competitive level can eliminate the deadweight loss of monopsony, bringing employment up to the efficient competitive level.

questions.question: The 'dynamic monopsony' concept accounts for:
options: Monopsony power that changes over time
questions.explanation: Dynamic monopsony considers how turnover costs, search frictions, and wage policies affect employer power over time, not just in static analysis.

questions.question: Compared to perfect competition, worker surplus in monopsony is:
questions.explanation: Worker surplus is reduced in monopsony because both wages and employment are lower than in competitive markets.

questions.question: Monopsony power can be mitigated by:
questions.explanation: Better job matching, reduced search costs, and improved worker mobility all reduce employers' monopsony power by increasing labor supply elasticity.

questions.question: In a monopsony labor market, the employer's surplus is:
options: The area below the wage and above the supply curve
The area above the wage and below the MRP curve
The entire area under the MRP curve
The difference between MFC and wage
questions.explanation: Employer surplus in monopsony is the area above the wage line and below the MRP curve, representing the difference between workers' productivity and their wages.

questions.question: The 'efficiency wage' model in monopsony suggests that employers might pay above the profit-maximizing wage to:
questions.explanation: Even monopsonists might pay efficiency wages to reduce turnover costs, increase worker effort, or attract better applicants, despite their market power.

questions.question: Modern research suggests monopsony power may be more common than previously thought due to:
options: Job search frictions and employer concentration
The absence of any market imperfections
questions.explanation: Recent evidence suggests search frictions, limited information, and employer concentration give many employers some degree of monopsony power, even in seemingly competitive markets.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You thoroughly understand monopsony power in labor markets and its implications for wages and employment.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basics but should review the MFC concept, profit-maximizing conditions, and policy implications.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: how monopsony differs from competition, the role of MFC, and why wages are lower in monopsony markets.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember that monopsony involves a single employer who pays lower wages and employs fewer workers than in competitive markets.
